Some fraction of them are in the Goldilocks zone, not too close, if it had liquid water it would evaporate, not too far, if it had liquid water it would freeze. now you can calculate what that is for any star. and so there's a subset of all the thousands of exoplanets. there's a few hundred that orbit in the Goldilocks zone. life as we know it could thrive there, haven't found life, still looking for life, but it could thrive there. by the way, there are other sources of heat, sources of heat from tides that are created from the main planet, Jupiter for example, on to its moons. so there are moons of Jupiter. Jupiter's way outside the Goldilocks zone. the moons of Jupiter are kept warm by this sort of gravitational massaging. it's called tidal heating. so you might have life as we know it on the moons of planets that have tidally heated those moons. so that opens the net. It casts a much wider net in the search for life in the universe

Current understanding suggests that within our galaxy alone, tens of billions of planets might be teeming with life, regardless of their surface temperature or atmospheric composition.

Neil DeGrasse Tyson, astrophysicist extraordinaire, went to Oregon to see it. But that's not what makes this story interesting - he took his telescope with him! He wanted to show people how much more spectacular an eclipse looks through a telescope compared to just looking up into the sun.
